description.narrative: The preservation and study of indigenous African musical traditions are cultural priorities in post-apartheid South Africa. title.narrative: Conservation of the Late Iron Age Ivory and Bone Tool Collections at the University of Pretoria and Mapungubwe Museums

description.narrative: A World Heritage site, Mapungubwe was the center of an extensive Iron Age trade network, and excavations since the 1930s have yielded important collections of bone and ivory artifacts. This project involves a conservation needs assessment and the design and installation of a suitable storage environment for the objects.

title.narrative: Capacity Enhancement for institutionalized victim centered investigations and prosecutions of Trafficking in Persons (TIP) Cases

description.narrative: The International Organization for Migration (IOM) will build the criminal justice process around a victim-centered approach by enhancing cooperation and coordination among members of the national TIP task forces. Project activities will include increasing the capacity of TIP knowledge among already established anti-TIP task forces to better identify TIP cases, revising and mainstreaming a counter trafficking curriculum into the training programs of targeted government departments, and developing and strengthening TIP data collection and reporting mechanisms.

title.narrative: Conservation of the Historical Collections of the Nelson Mandela Centre of Memory in Johannesburg

description.narrative: The centers collection consists of historic posters, photographs, manuscripts, and other materials documenting the struggle to end apartheid. Much of this archive is acidified paper and highly susceptible to degradation. The project involves systematic de-acidification of the collection in preparation for its transfer to refurbished collections storage space.

title.narrative: Preservation of the 19th- and Early 20th-Century Archives of Inanda Seminary

description.narrative: To support the preservation of the 19th- and early 20th-century archives of Inanda Seminary, the first boarding high school for black girls in southern Africa. Established in 1869, Inanda was the only school for black students not forced to adopt South Africas restrictive Apartheid-era Bantu education policy. The schools alumni include distinguished women in southern African politics, medicine, business, and other sectors. This project focuses on the preventive conservation and display of the historical documents and complements efforts underway to restore the historic seminary buildings.

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

description.narrative: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) will train criminal justice personnel (judges, magistrates, prosecutors, law enforcement, etc.) at the national and regional level in identified Southern African countries to increase the number of systematized, victim-centered human trafficking investigations and prosecutions. UNODC will conduct regional criminal justice personnel workshops to share promising practices in the successful investigation and prosecution of human trafficking cases. This project will ensure that all trainings include a victim-centered approach and build the capacity of criminal justice personnel to identify victims and refer them to the appropriate protection services. All trainings will include a training-of-trainers component and provide case consultation to training participants as needed.
